{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3666517,"name":"ScottRandallWay","username":"ScottRandallWay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/73ab20/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-27T16:28:11.801Z","cooked":"

I noticed if you put in a thread wait into a command the framework does not like it. You’ll get an exception, because you cause an interruption. I have a command where I want the motor to run a bit longer (one second maybe) after the isFinished condition has been detected. I came up with this hack. Was wondering if this is a bad idea or if there is a better way to do this.

So I know the isFinished will run very 20ms. So I just put a local int variable in the command. I set it to 0 in the constructor. In the isFinished if my isFinished condition is true I increment the counter. Then I check the counter to determine if it has iterated the appropriate number of times. So for 1 second I need 50 iterations (20ms * 50). If it has reached 50 iterations then isFinished returns true.

Is this an appropriate approach or is there a better way?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-27T16:28:11.801Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":115.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503695,"topic_slug":"adding-delay-to-command","display_username":"ScottRandallWay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25653,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/adding-delay-to-command/503695/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3666520,"name":"Matt Soucy (he/him)","username":"msoucy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msoucy/{size}/237623_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-27T16:34:59.914Z","cooked":"

To do this in the command-based framework, you’d probably want to make a sequential command group. The first item in the sequence would be your existing command, then a WaitCommand, and then the command to turn off the motor.

In general we recommend building commands with factories and composition rather than subclassing.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-27T18:57:16.763Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":211,"readers_count":210,"score":72.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503695,"topic_slug":"adding-delay-to-command","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/adding-delay-to-command/503695/3","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3667113,"name":"Justin Nesselrotte","username":"jnesselr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnesselr/{size}/199903_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-28T02:28:48.004Z","cooked":"
ScottRandallWay:

So I know the isFinished will run very 20ms. So I just put a local int variable in the command. I set it to 0 in the constructor. In the isFinished if my isFinished condition is true I increment the counter. Then I check the counter to determine if it has iterated the appropriate number of times. So for 1 second I need 50 iterations (20ms * 50). If it has reached 50 iterations then isFinished returns true.

One thing that hasn’t been pointed out is that that’s not a great way to do time counting in pseudo real time systems like what we’re doing in FRC.

The reason why is because that 20 ms timing might be inaccurate due to a lot of reasons. Like. A lot a lot. Most of them end up skewing your code to increment later instead of incrementing earlier. In fact, the only one that would tend to skew your code earlier that I can think of is if the command scheduler removes earlier scheduled commands, making yours move earlier within a loop frame.

Point of the matter is, you can’t trust it. WPILib has a Timer class that works great if you want to check if some amount of time has passed. It will be far more accurate than simply counting the iterations.

I think both options are valid. There’s pros and cons to each approach. With subclassing, using the Timer is the correct move. There’s also subtle differences in timing between chaining a wait command vs handling the timer internally that may be important.

jnesselr:

subtle differences

Could you elaborate on this? I’m curious to know what wouldn’t be the same, because the internal implementation of WaitCommand uses a Timer anyways.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-29T20:39:54.692Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":39.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503695,"topic_slug":"adding-delay-to-command","display_username":"Nolan Barker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/src-html/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj2/command/WaitCommand.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Source code","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/adding-delay-to-command/503695/8","custom_user_title":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3668981,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-29T21:38:23.213Z","cooked":"

If you don’t code the use of the Timer class correctly, then it won’t work right.

If you code the use of the Timer class exactly as the WaitCommand does, then obviously it will work but why duplicate what others have already coded for you?

And it is best as others point out above to use the Wait factory that I linked to. Reduced amount of code is concise, faster to code, easier to read and understand - less prone to errors for all involved.

Use of the factories and composites emphasize the Robot action problem being solved instead of being concerned with how the solution was coded in the programming language. That is the Command factories and compositions are the language of your problem instead of using more code to show how to accomplish a solution in Java, C++, etc.

I believe @Oblarg has referred to this “as working in the problem state instead of the solution state.” The fun part for most roboticists is making the robot move to our command and it’s generally a bit tedious and error prone to have to worry about how exactly to accomplish that with basic Java statements with your own design of state machines, etc. Command Based is the customized language of robot action - basic Java is not and factories and compositions are your friends to ease Command Based coding.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-29T21:38:23.213Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":42.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503695,"topic_slug":"adding-delay-to-command","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65568,"username":"therekrab","name":"Nolan Barker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/adding-delay-to-command/503695/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3670126,"name":"Justin Nesselrotte","username":"jnesselr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnesselr/{size}/199903_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-30T04:27:36.860Z","cooked":"

The primary difference is when and how the timer is initiated. In a sequential command group, if the current command finishes, the next one is initialized in the same loop. For the wait command, that means it’s restarted and you’re golden. i.e., doing some work and then starting a timer and having your isFinished return the timer.hasElapsed call results in the exact same thing as a sequential command doing that work and then following it up with a wait command. If you’re doing anything outside of that, then you have more control over how the timer gets set up, when it starts, restarts, or is reset.

The one subtlety that I was thinking through when I originally wrote that is that if your work and timer both start in initialize in a custom command, they’ll start at the same time. If you have a sequential command and your first command (say to move a motor) is an instant command, then that will run in the sequential initialization. During the execute portion, execute will be called and do nothing, isFinished returns true, and then the initialize gets called on your wait command. This means your wait command starts ~20ms later than if they were in the same subclassed command. I said “subtle” because at this scale, those 20 ms probably don’t matter.
